The rain hammered against the grimy window of cell block C, each droplet racing down the glass like tears on a weathered face. Lars Eriksson pressed his palm against the cold concrete wall and closed his eyes, letting the sound transport him somewhere else entirely. In his mind, he wasn't here in Kumla Prison, wasn't wearing the standard-issue gray uniform that scratched against his skin, wasn't counting down the days until his parole hearing. Instead, he was back in his cramped apartment on Hisingen, wrench in hand, the familiar weight of honest work settling into his bones.

The fantasy had begun innocently enough, during those first sleepless nights when the reality of his situation felt too crushing to bear. Twenty-five years for armed robbery, they'd said. Twenty-five years for a moment of desperation that had lasted less than ten minutes but would define the rest of his life. So he'd started writing, scribbling stories on whatever paper he could find, creating an alternate version of himself who had never walked into that bank on Avenyn, never pointed a shaking gun at the terrified teller, never heard the sirens growing closer as he stumbled out onto the street with a bag full of money that had felt like ash in his hands.

In his stories, Lars the plumber lived a different life. He fixed pipes and unclogged drains and came home each evening to a simple dinner and the evening news. He paid his taxes and complained about the weather and worried about normal things like mortgage payments and whether his old Volvo would pass inspection. It was a boring life, perhaps, but it was clean in ways that Lars the prisoner could barely remember being.

The scratching of his pen against the notebook had become a nightly ritual, the only thing that kept the walls from closing in completely. His cellmate Mikael thought he was writing letters to some imaginary girlfriend, and Lars never bothered to correct him. Let him think what he wanted. The truth was far stranger and more pathetic than fiction could ever be.

Tonight, as the storm raged outside and the fluorescent lights buzzed overhead with their endless electrical hum, Lars opened his notebook to a fresh page and let his mind drift back to his alternate self. In this version of reality, Lars Eriksson had grown tired of the endless cycle of broken pipes and backed-up toilets. He'd started dreaming of something different, something that didn't involve crawling through other people's filth for a living.

The idea had come to him gradually, like water seeping through cracks in old mortar. What if he simply disappeared? Not in any dramatic fashion, not like some movie where the hero fakes his death and starts over with a new identity. Just a quiet withdrawal from the world, a gentle stepping back from the noise and chaos of modern life. He could buy a small plot of land somewhere outside the city, build a simple cabin with his own hands, grow his own food. Live like people had lived for centuries before smartphones and traffic jams and the constant pressure to consume, to produce, to be someone important.

The more Lars thought about it, the more appealing the idea became. He'd always been good with his hands, could fix anything that broke and build anything he could imagine. He had some money saved up, not much but enough to buy a few acres in Värmland or maybe up in Dalarna where land was still cheap and neighbors were scarce. He could raise chickens, maybe a goat or two. Learn to preserve food for the winter, to read weather patterns in the clouds, to find satisfaction in simple tasks done well.

Of course, when he'd finally worked up the courage to mention his plan to his brother Nils over Sunday dinner, the reaction had been predictably harsh.

"Have you lost your mind completely?" Nils had said, setting down his coffee cup with enough force to rattle the saucer. "A hermit? What are you, some kind of religious fanatic now?"

Their sister Astrid had been only slightly more diplomatic. "I think what Nils means is that it seems like a very isolated way to live. What about your friends? Your work? You've built up a good reputation as a plumber."

Lars had tried to explain that he was tired of his reputation, tired of being known as the guy you called when your bathroom flooded at three in the morning. He wanted to be known by the deer that might drink from the stream behind his cabin, by the birds that would nest in the trees he planted. He wanted to measure his days by the sun's movement across the sky rather than by the relentless ticking of his phone's clock.

But they couldn't understand, any of them. His mother had cried and accused him of abandoning the family. His ex-wife Helena had called him selfish and irresponsible, though why she cared what he did with his life after their divorce was beyond his comprehension. Even his old friend Gunnar from trade school had shaken his head and muttered something about midlife crisis and suggested he buy a motorcycle instead.

Only his gardener had seemed to understand. This was perhaps the strangest part of Lars's imagined life, the detail that had surprised even him when it emerged from his subconscious onto the page. In reality, Lars had never employed a gardener, had never even had a proper garden beyond a few wilted herbs on his apartment balcony. But in his alternate life, he'd inherited a small house with a decent-sized yard, and maintaining it had proven beyond his abilities. Enter Erik Lindqvist, a man perhaps ten years younger than Lars with dirt permanently embedded under his fingernails and an encyclopedic knowledge of soil composition and growing seasons.

Erik was quiet by nature, the sort of person who could work alongside you for hours without feeling the need to fill the silence with meaningless chatter. When Lars had explained his hermit plan, Erik had simply nodded and continued pruning the rosebush he'd been working on.

"Makes sense," he'd said finally. "Too many people in the world think they need to be around other people all the time. Nothing wrong with solitude if that's what feeds your soul."

It was Erik who had helped Lars research properties, who had driven with him to look at potential sites, who had offered practical advice about things like water sources and soil quality and how to determine if a piece of land was truly as isolated as it appeared. He'd even volunteered to help with the initial building, to stay for a week or two and help Lars construct the basic framework of his new life before leaving him to his chosen solitude.

But then everything had changed, as things have a way of doing when you least expect them. The change had come not through any fault or decision of Lars's, but through Erik's actions, through a moment of violence that had transformed both their lives in ways neither could have anticipated.

It had happened on a Tuesday evening in late September, when the days were growing shorter and the leaves were just beginning to turn. Erik had been working late, trying to finish winterizing the garden before the first frost arrived. Lars had gone inside to prepare dinner, leaving Erik alone with his thoughts and his work. Later, Lars would wonder if things might have been different if he'd stayed outside, if his presence might have prevented what happened next.

The man who appeared in the garden that evening was a stranger to Lars, though Erik seemed to recognize him immediately. From his kitchen window, Lars could see them talking, could observe the tension in their body language even if he couldn't hear their words. Erik had straightened up from the flower bed he'd been working in, his hands still holding the small spade he'd been using to plant bulbs for next spring. The stranger was gesticulating wildly, his face red with anger or alcohol or both.Lars had watched from the window as the confrontation escalated, his dinner forgotten on the stove behind him. The stranger stepped closer to Erik, jabbing his finger toward Erik's chest in an aggressive manner that made Lars's stomach tighten with unease. Even through the glass, he could see the way Erik's shoulders tensed, the careful manner in which he set down his gardening tools and took a step backward. There was something in Erik's posture that spoke of experience with violence, a weary recognition that this situation was spiraling beyond the point of reasonable discourse.

The sound of raised voices finally penetrated the window, though Lars still couldn't make out individual words. He found himself moving toward the back door, his hand already reaching for the handle, when everything changed in the space between one heartbeat and the next. The stranger lunged forward, his hands outstretched toward Erik's throat, and Erik's response was swift and decisive. The gardening spade, which moments before had been used to plant bulbs that would bloom in the spring, became something else entirely as it connected with the stranger's skull with a sound that carried clearly across the yard despite the closed window.

Lars stood frozen in his doorway as the stranger crumpled to the ground, his body folding in on itself like a marionette whose strings had been suddenly severed. Erik remained standing over him, the bloodied spade still gripped in his hands, his chest rising and falling with rapid, shallow breaths. For a long moment, neither of them moved, as if the weight of what had just occurred needed time to settle into the space between them like dust after an explosion.

When Erik finally looked up and met Lars's eyes through the gathering darkness, his face was pale but eerily calm. He dropped the spade beside the motionless figure and walked slowly toward the house, his work boots leaving dark prints on the grass that was already beginning to glisten with evening dew. Lars stepped aside to let him pass, and Erik moved directly to the kitchen sink, where he began washing his hands with the methodical thoroughness of a surgeon preparing for an operation.

"He's dead," Erik said without turning around, his voice carrying no more emotion than if he were commenting on the weather. "I felt his skull give way under the blade. There's no coming back from that kind of damage." He continued scrubbing his hands, the water running pink as it swirled down the drain, and Lars found himself noting the strange domesticity of the scene. Here was a man who had just committed murder, calmly using the same sink where Lars washed his breakfast dishes each morning.

Lars moved to the window and looked out at the still figure lying among the flower beds. From this distance, the man looked almost peaceful, as if he had simply decided to take a nap among the chrysanthemums that Erik had planted the week before. But there was something unnatural about the angle of his head, something that spoke clearly of the finality of what had transpired in those few seconds of violence.

"Who was he?" Lars asked, surprised by the steadiness of his own voice. He had expected to feel panic, horror, the urgent need to call the police and report what had happened. Instead, he found himself filled with a strange sense of calm, as if this moment had been inevitable from the beginning, written into the fabric of their relationship long before either of them had recognized it.

Erik finished washing his hands and dried them carefully on the kitchen towel that hung beside the sink. He folded the towel with precise movements and set it back in its place before finally turning to face Lars. His eyes held a weight that hadn't been there an hour earlier, the kind of burden that settles permanently into a person's bones once they've crossed certain lines.

"His name was Marcus Holmberg," Erik said, moving to the kitchen table and sinking into one of the wooden chairs that Lars had inherited from his grandmother. "We grew up in the same neighborhood in Angered. He's been looking for me for almost three years now, ever since I testified against him in a case involving his younger brother." Erik's hands lay flat on the table's surface, and Lars noticed that despite the thorough washing, there was still dirt embedded beneath his fingernails from the evening's gardening work.

The story that emerged over the next hour was one of old grudges and family loyalty taken to dangerous extremes. Marcus's brother David had been involved in a drug-related shooting that had left two people wounded and a third permanently paralyzed. Erik had witnessed the incident while walking home from work late one evening, had seen David Holmberg fire the shots that had shattered three families and sent ripples of trauma through an entire community. When the police had come asking questions, Erik had done what he believed was right, had told the truth about what he had seen despite the warnings from neighbors who understood the potential consequences of cooperation with authorities.

David Holmberg had been sentenced to twelve years in prison, and Marcus had sworn vengeance against the man whose testimony had sealed his brother's fate. Erik had been forced to leave Angered, to abandon the small landscaping business he had built over years of careful work, to essentially disappear from his old life and start over somewhere new. He had thought that taking the job as Lars's gardener would provide the anonymity and peace he needed, that a quiet residential neighborhood far from his old haunts would offer sanctuary from the ghosts of his past.

"I should have known he would find me eventually," Erik continued, his voice taking on the flat, resigned tone of a man who has accepted the inevitable. "Marcus was always persistent, even as a child. He never forgot a slight, never forgave anyone who crossed his family. I suppose I thought that three years would be enough, that he would move on to other concerns and leave me to live my life in peace."

Lars found himself studying Erik's face in the soft light of the kitchen lamp, searching for signs of remorse or fear or any of the emotions he imagined should accompany such a confession. Instead, he saw only a deep weariness, the exhaustion of a man who had been running for years and had finally been forced to stop and turn and face his pursuer. There was something almost liberating about Erik's expression, as if the act of killing Marcus Holmberg had freed him from a burden he had carried for far too long.

"What do we do now?" Lars asked, and even as the words left his mouth, he was struck by his use of the plural pronoun. When had this become a shared problem rather than Erik's crisis alone? He should be calling the police, should be distancing himself from what had happened in his garden, should be thinking about his own safety and reputation. Instead, he found himself mentally cataloging the tools in his garage, wondering which ones might be useful for digging, calculating how long it would take to dispose of a body in a way that would never be discovered.

Erik looked at him with something that might have been gratitude mixed with surprise. "You don't have to involve yourself in this," he said carefully. "This is my problem, my choice, my consequences to face. You could call the police right now and tell them you witnessed a murder in your garden. Claim you were too shocked to intervene, too frightened to act. No one would blame you for that reaction."

But even as Erik offered him an escape route, Lars knew with certainty that he would not take it. Something had shifted in the space between Marcus Holmberg's death and this moment, some fundamental alteration in his understanding of himself and his place in the world. For years, he had lived a careful, measured existence, paying his taxes and following rules and never coloring outside the lines that society had drawn for him. He had been Lars the reliable plumber, Lars the responsible citizen, Lars the man who could be counted on to do the right thing according to other people's definitions of rightness.

But as he looked out at the body lying in his garden, at the man who had helped him plant flowers and plan his escape to a hermit's life, Lars felt something wake up inside him that had been sleeping for years. It was a recognition of possibility, of the freedom that comes when you finally step outside the boundaries that have defined your existence. Marcus Holmberg had come to Erik's garden seeking violence and had found death instead, but his death had inadvertently opened a door that Lars had never even known existed.

"We bury him," Lars said, the words coming out with a decisiveness that surprised them both. "Tonight, while the rain covers any sound we might make. My neighbor to the east is visiting her daughter in Stockholm this week, and the Peterssons on the west side sleep like the dead once they've had their evening wine. We dig a hole deep enough that he'll never be found, and then we plant something on top of it. Something that will grow and thrive and make the spot look like it's been undisturbed for years."

Erik stared at him for a long moment, and Lars could see him reassessing everything he thought he knew about the quiet plumber who had hired him to tend a modest suburban garden. "You understand what you're suggesting," Erik said finally. "If we do this, there's no going back. We become accomplices, conspirators. We become criminals."

The word hung in the air between them like smoke from a fire that could not be extinguished. Criminals. Lars turned the concept over in his mind, examining it from different angles, and found that it did not frighten him as much as he had expected it would. Perhaps because he had already been planning to withdraw from society anyway, the prospect of placing himself permanently outside its laws seemed less like a catastrophe and more like an acceleration of an inevitable process.**Chapter 2**

The rain continued its relentless assault on the windows as Lars and Erik prepared for the work ahead of them. In the harsh fluorescent light of the garage, they moved with the careful efficiency of men who understood that their freedom depended on the thoroughness of their actions. Lars had changed into his oldest work clothes, garments already stained with years of plumbing emergencies and home repair projects, while Erik remained in the earth-stained clothing he had been wearing when Marcus Holmberg arrived to settle old scores in a suburban garden.

The tools they gathered seemed almost mundane in their ordinariness: two shovels with worn wooden handles, a pickaxe for breaking through the harder clay soil beneath the topsoil, a wheelbarrow to transport the displaced earth, and a collection of plastic tarps that Lars had accumulated over years of protecting furniture during various home improvement projects. They worked in near silence, communicating through glances and gestures, as if speaking aloud might somehow make their intentions more real or more damning.

Erik had suggested a location near the back corner of the property, where a cluster of mature birch trees would provide natural camouflage and where the existing landscape would make the disturbance of fresh digging less noticeable. The spot was also conveniently distant from the house, far enough that any future settling of the soil would not threaten the foundation or require explanation to visiting utility workers or curious neighbors. It was the kind of practical thinking that Lars was beginning to associate with his gardener, the same methodical approach that Erik brought to pruning roses or planning seasonal plantings.

They had wrapped Marcus Holmberg's body in one of the plastic tarps, securing it with duct tape in a manner that was both respectful and efficient. The dead man's face was mercifully covered, allowing them to think of their burden as simply another landscaping project rather than the mortal remains of someone who had walked into this garden with his own plans and grievances and expectations for how the evening would unfold. Lars found himself grateful for this small mercy, for the way the blue plastic transformed a human tragedy into something more manageable and less likely to haunt his dreams.

The digging proved more difficult than either man had anticipated, despite Erik's familiarity with the soil composition and drainage patterns of the property. The recent rain had turned the upper layers into a sticky, clinging mud that adhered to their shovels and made each scoop of earth a laborious process. Below that, they encountered the dense clay that Lars remembered from when he had installed the French drain along the foundation three years earlier, clay that required the pickaxe and considerable effort to break apart into manageable chunks.

They took turns with the more strenuous work, one man digging while the other served as lookout and rested muscles that were unaccustomed to such sustained physical labor. Lars discovered that his years of crawling through cramped spaces and wrestling with stubborn pipes had given him a wiry strength that served him well in this endeavor, while Erik's daily work in gardens and landscapes had developed the kind of endurance that allowed him to maintain a steady rhythm even as fatigue began to accumulate in his shoulders and back.

By midnight, they had excavated a hole approximately seven feet long, four feet wide, and nearly six feet deep. The dimensions were generous by necessity, allowing not only for the body but also for the layer of lime that Erik had retrieved from the garden shed, a substance intended to accelerate decomposition and minimize any odors that might eventually attract the attention of animals or inquisitive humans. The lime also served a psychological function, transforming their act of concealment into something more clinical and less personal, as if they were following a recipe rather than improvising their way through their first experience with the disposal of human remains.

The actual placement of Marcus Holmberg's body into the excavated grave proved to be a moment of unexpected solemnity. Despite the violent circumstances of his death and the practical necessities that had brought them to this point, both men found themselves moving with careful deliberation, lowering their burden with a gentleness that seemed to acknowledge the finality and significance of what they were doing. Erik spoke a few quiet words in Swedish, something that sounded like a prayer or perhaps simply an expression of regret for the chain of events that had made this burial necessary.

The process of filling the hole required another two hours of steady work, complicated by their need to distribute the displaced soil in a way that would not create obvious mounds or depressions in the surrounding landscape. Erik's expertise proved invaluable here, as he directed the placement of different soil types to create drainage patterns that would support the plantings he was already envisioning for the site. They reserved the richest topsoil for the final layer, creating a growing medium that would encourage rapid establishment of whatever vegetation they chose to install over their secret.

As dawn began to lighten the eastern horizon, they stood beside the transformed corner of the garden, their clothes soaked through with rain and perspiration, their hands cramped from hours of gripping shovel handles, their bodies aching with the particular fatigue that comes from sustained physical labor performed under emotional stress. The site looked remarkably unremarkable, just another section of disturbed earth in a garden that showed signs of recent work throughout its boundaries. Erik had already begun sketching mental plans for a small meditation garden in the location, complete with a stone bench and carefully chosen perennials that would create year-round interest while establishing deep root systems to further secure their secret.

They returned the tools to the garage and stripped out of their muddy clothing in the utility room, Lars providing Erik with clean garments and accepting the strange intimacy that such circumstances created between them. The shared experience of the night had altered their relationship in ways that neither man fully understood yet, transforming employer and employee into something more complex and binding. They were now bound together by mutual culpability, by shared knowledge that could destroy them both if revealed, by the understanding that their lives had become permanently intertwined through violence and its concealment.

Over coffee and the simple breakfast that Lars prepared while Erik showered away the evidence of their night's work, they began to discuss the practical implications of what they had done. Marcus Holmberg would eventually be missed by someone, would become the subject of police inquiries and perhaps media attention if his disappearance stretched on long enough without explanation. Erik would need to account for his own whereabouts on the evening in question, would need to construct alibis and explanations that could withstand scrutiny without implicating Lars or drawing attention to the garden where Marcus had met his end.

The strange thing, Lars reflected as he watched Erik spread jam on toast with the same careful attention he brought to all his activities, was how natural this felt. The horror and panic he had expected to experience seemed to have been replaced by a sense of completion, as if some essential element of his life had finally clicked into place. For years, he had felt like an observer of his own existence, going through the motions of being Lars Eriksson without ever fully inhabiting the role. But last night, standing in his garden with dirt under his fingernails and a dead man's blood on his conscience, he had felt more authentically himself than he could remember being in decades.

Erik seemed to sense the direction of his thoughts. "You're not what I expected," he said, setting down his coffee cup and studying Lars with eyes that held new respect mixed with curiosity. "Most people would have called the police immediately, would have wanted nothing to do with cleaning up someone else's mess. But you stepped in without hesitation, as if you'd been waiting for exactly this kind of situation your entire life."

Lars considered this observation while he finished his eggs, recognizing the truth in Erik's words even as he struggled to understand its implications. Had he been waiting for this? Had some part of him been hoping for an excuse to step outside the boundaries of his ordinary life, to discover what kind of person he might become if freed from the expectations and constraints that had shaped his existence for nearly five decades? The hermit fantasy that had consumed so much of his mental energy suddenly seemed pale and insubstantial compared to the immediate reality of what they had accomplished together in the darkness of his garden.

"Maybe I was tired of being the kind of person who always does the right thing," Lars said finally. "Maybe I wanted to find out what it felt like to choose something else, something that mattered more than following rules that other people made for their own convenience." He looked out the kitchen window toward the corner of the garden where Marcus Holmberg now lay beneath six feet of carefully distributed soil, and felt a satisfaction that was both disturbing and exhilarating.

Erik nodded as if this explanation made perfect sense to him. "The thing about crossing certain lines," he said, "is that once you've done it, you can never really go back to believing that the lines meant anything in the first place. They become arbitrary markers rather than moral imperatives, suggestions rather than commandments." He paused to sip his coffee, and Lars noticed that his hands were steady despite everything they had done with those hands over the past few hours.

The conversation was interrupted by the sound of a car door slamming in the driveway next door, followed by the familiar voice of Mrs. Andersson greeting her cat with the kind of enthusiasm usually reserved for long-lost relatives. Both men tensed momentarily, their new criminal instincts alerting them to potential threats and complications, before remembering that Mrs. Andersson's return from visiting her daughter had always been scheduled for this morning. She would spend the day unpacking and catching up on neighborhood gossip, activities that would keep her safely occupied while any remaining evidence of their night's work dried and settled into invisibility.

As Erik prepared to leave for what they were now thinking of as his regular gardening duties at other properties, they established the basic framework for their new relationship. Erik would continue his work maintaining Lars's garden, but their interactions would now include additional layers of communication and mutual support. They would meet regularly to assess potential risks and adjust their strategies for maintaining their secret, and Erik would gradually implement his plans for transforming the burial site into a feature that would discourage future excavation while serving as a living memorial to their shared transgression.

More importantly, they had begun to discuss Lars's hermit plans with renewed seriousness, recognizing that his withdrawal from society had acquired new urgency and practical advantages in light of recent developments. A man living in isolation would be less likely to face scrutiny from law enforcement, less likely to encounter situations where nervous behavior or guilty knowledge might betray him, less likely to maintain the kinds of social connections that could become complicated if questions about Marcus Holmberg's disappearance ever led investigators to this quiet suburban neighborhood.

Erik had volunteered to help accelerate the timeline for Lars's retreat from civilization, offering not only his planned assistance with construction and setup but also his expertise in selecting a property that would provide maximum security and minimum contact with potentially problematic neighbors or officials. They could begin the search immediately, could perhaps have Lars established in his new hermit existence within a matter of months rather than the years he had originally envisioned for the transition.

The prospect filled Lars with an excitement that had nothing to do with escaping civilization and everything to do with the possibility of continuing and deepening his partnership with the man who had brought such unexpected transformation to his life. Erik had proven himself to be exactly the kind of person Lars had never known he needed: practical, decisive, untroubled by conventional morality, and apparently as eager as Lars himself to explore the implications of their new status as criminals and conspirators.

As he watched Erik gather his tools and prepare to depart for his other obligations, Lars felt a sense of anticipation that reminded him of childhood Christmas mornings, when the day ahead had seemed full of unlimited possibility and wonderful surprises. For the first time in years, he had something to look forward to, something that belonged entirely to him and Erik and their shared understanding of what they had accomplished together in the darkness of a suburban garden where a dead man now nourished the roots of carefully planted flowers.**Chapter 3**

The days following Marcus Holmberg's burial settled into a rhythm that surprised Lars with its normalcy. He had expected guilt to gnaw at him during quiet moments, had anticipated sleepless nights filled with paranoid imaginings of police investigations and forensic discoveries. Instead, he found himself sleeping more soundly than he had in months, waking each morning with a sense of purpose that had been absent from his life for longer than he cared to remember. The knowledge of what lay beneath the birch trees at the corner of his property felt less like a burden and more like a secret source of strength, a reminder that he was capable of decisive action when circumstances demanded it.

Erik arrived each morning at precisely eight o'clock, carrying his familiar canvas tool bag and wearing the same expression of quiet competence that had first attracted Lars to hire him months earlier. To any observer, their relationship would appear unchanged from what it had been before that rainy Tuesday evening when everything had shifted between them. Erik continued his methodical care of the flower beds and lawn areas, continued his patient explanations of seasonal gardening tasks and plant care requirements, continued to work with the same unhurried thoroughness that characterized all his activities. But beneath this surface continuity, both men were acutely aware of the new dimension that had been added to their daily interactions.

They had developed a subtle system of communication that allowed them to discuss sensitive matters without attracting attention from neighbors or passersby who might overhear fragments of conversation. When Erik needed to report something potentially significant, he would mention problems with drainage in the back corner of the property, leading to detailed discussions about soil composition and water management that served as cover for more crucial exchanges of information. When Lars wanted to share concerns about their security or discuss modifications to their plans, he would ask questions about winter preparation for the garden, creating opportunities for lengthy conversations that appeared entirely innocent to casual observation.

The meditation garden that Erik had envisioned for the burial site began to take shape with remarkable speed and attention to detail. He had designed the space around a central grouping of three large stones that he claimed to have sourced from a demolition project in the city, though Lars suspected they had actually been carefully selected from a quarry specifically for their weight and permanence. The stones were positioned to create natural seating while simultaneously marking the precise boundaries of the disturbed earth beneath them, serving both aesthetic and practical functions in their new landscape design. Between and around the stones, Erik had planted a carefully chosen selection of deep-rooted perennials that would establish extensive underground systems over the coming seasons, further securing their secret while creating year-round visual interest.

The plant selection revealed Erik's sophisticated understanding of both horticulture and psychology. He had chosen species that would thrive in the specific soil conditions created by their modifications to the site, plants that would grow vigorously and require minimal maintenance once established, varieties that would discourage casual digging or disturbance through either their root systems or their visual impact. Lavender and rosemary provided aromatic qualities that would mask any potential odors while attracting beneficial insects that would make the area seem naturally vibrant and healthy. Ornamental grasses created movement and seasonal interest while establishing the kind of dense root networks that would make future excavation both difficult and obviously destructive to the established landscape.

Most cleverly, Erik had incorporated several small fruit-bearing shrubs into the design, creating what appeared to be a productive element of the garden that would justify regular attention and care from both men throughout the growing seasons. Blueberry bushes and currant plants provided legitimate reasons for them to spend time in the area, to water and fertilize and prune in ways that would maintain the health and vigor of everything growing above their buried secret. The annual cycle of caring for these plants would also ensure that the site received consistent attention that would allow them to monitor its condition and address any potential problems before they could develop into serious threats to their security.

Beyond the practical advantages of Erik's design, Lars found himself genuinely moved by the beauty and serenity of what they were creating together. The meditation garden was becoming exactly the kind of space its name suggested, a place where someone could sit quietly and contemplate the mysteries of existence while surrounded by carefully orchestrated natural beauty. The irony of using such a peaceful setting to conceal evidence of violence was not lost on him, but rather than finding this disturbing, he discovered that it added layers of meaning and complexity that made the space more interesting and personally significant than any ordinary garden feature could have been.

During their coffee breaks and lunch conversations, Lars and Erik had begun exploring the philosophical implications of their situation with the kind of intellectual curiosity that neither man had expected to find in the other. Erik, despite his practical focus and working-class background, revealed himself to be surprisingly well-read and thoughtful about questions of morality and justice that their actions had forced them to confront directly. He spoke knowledgeably about philosophers and writers who had grappled with similar questions about the relationship between individual conscience and social expectations, about the circumstances under which ordinary people might find themselves compelled to step outside legal and moral boundaries that had previously seemed inviolate.

Lars discovered that his partner in crime possessed a sophisticated understanding of historical examples of resistance to unjust authority, of situations throughout human history when the preservation of individual dignity or survival had required people to reject the moral frameworks imposed by their societies. Erik spoke with particular insight about the choices faced by ordinary citizens during times of political upheaval, when the difference between collaboration and resistance often came down to split-second decisions made under extreme pressure by people who had never expected to find themselves in such circumstances. Their own situation was obviously different in scale and context, but the underlying questions about personal responsibility and moral autonomy were surprisingly similar.

These conversations had an unexpected effect on Lars's understanding of his own motivations and desires. The hermit fantasy that had dominated his thinking for months began to evolve into something more complex and ambitious than simple withdrawal from society. Instead of merely escaping the pressures and expectations of modern life, he began to envision a more active rejection of the values and assumptions that had shaped his existence for nearly fifty years. The idea of living according to his own moral code rather than society's rules became increasingly appealing, especially when he had Erik as a partner who shared his willingness to prioritize practical outcomes over abstract principles.

The research into suitable properties for Lars's retreat had intensified and become more focused as their criteria evolved beyond simple isolation and affordability. They were now looking for locations that would provide not just privacy but also strategic advantages for people who might need to avoid official scrutiny or unexpected visitors with problematic agendas. Erik had contacts in rural communities throughout central Sweden, people who understood the value of discretion and minded their own business as a matter of both principle and practical necessity. Through these connections, they had identified several promising possibilities that combined the solitude Lars desired with the security that their new circumstances made essential.

One property in particular had captured their attention and imagination. Located in a remote valley in Härjedalen, nearly two hours' drive from the nearest town of any size, the land consisted of forty-seven acres of mixed forest and meadow surrounding a small lake that had no public access or significant recreational use. The rain hammered against the grimy window of cell block C, each droplet racing down the glass like tears on a weathered face. Lars Eriksson pressed his palm against the cold concrete wall and closed his eyes, letting the sound transport him somewhere else entirely. In his mind, he wasn't here in Kumla Prison, wasn't wearing the standard-issue gray uniform that scratched against his skin, wasn't counting down the days until his parole hearing. Instead, he was back in his cramped apartment on Hisingen, wrench in hand, the familiar weight of honest work settling into his bones.

The fantasy had begun innocently enough, during those first sleepless nights when the reality of his situation felt too crushing to bear. Twenty-five years for armed robbery, they'd said. Twenty-five years for a moment of desperation that had lasted less than ten minutes but would define the rest of his life. So he'd started writing, scribbling stories on whatever paper he could find, creating an alternate version of himself who had never walked into that bank on Avenyn, never pointed a shaking gun at the terrified teller, never heard the sirens growing closer as he stumbled out onto the street with a bag full of money that had felt like ash in his hands.

In his stories, Lars the plumber lived a different life. He fixed pipes and unclogged drains and came home each evening to a simple dinner and the evening news. He paid his taxes and complained about the weather and worried about normal things like mortgage payments and whether his old Volvo would pass inspection. It was a boring life, perhaps, but it was clean in ways that Lars the prisoner could barely remember being.

The scratching of his pen against the notebook had become a nightly ritual, the only thing that kept the walls from closing in completely. His cellmate Mikael thought he was writing letters to some imaginary girlfriend, and Lars never bothered to correct him. Let him think what he wanted. The truth was far stranger and more pathetic than fiction could ever be.

Tonight, as the storm raged outside and the fluorescent lights buzzed overhead with their endless electrical hum, Lars opened his notebook to a fresh page and let his mind drift back to his alternate self. In this version of reality, Lars Eriksson had grown tired of the endless cycle of broken pipes and backed-up toilets. He'd started dreaming of something different, something that didn't involve crawling through other people's filth for a living.

The idea had come to him gradually, like water seeping through cracks in old mortar. What if he simply disappeared? Not in any dramatic fashion, not like some movie where the hero fakes his death and starts over with a new identity. Just a quiet withdrawal from the world, a gentle stepping back from the noise and chaos of modern life. He could buy a small plot of land somewhere outside the city, build a simple cabin with his own hands, grow his own food. Live like people had lived for centuries before smartphones and traffic jams and the constant pressure to consume, to produce, to be someone important.

The more Lars thought about it, the more appealing the idea became. He'd always been good with his hands, could fix anything that broke and build anything he could imagine. He had some money saved up, not much but enough to buy a few acres in Värmland or maybe up in Dalarna where land was still cheap and neighbors were scarce. He could raise chickens, maybe a goat or two. Learn to preserve food for the winter, to read weather patterns in the clouds, to find satisfaction in simple tasks done well.

Of course, when he'd finally worked up the courage to mention his plan to his brother Nils over Sunday dinner, the reaction had been predictably harsh.

"Have you lost your mind completely?" Nils had said, setting down his coffee cup with enough force to rattle the saucer. "A hermit? What are you, some kind of religious fanatic now?"

Their sister Astrid had been only slightly more diplomatic. "I think what Nils means is that it seems like a very isolated way to live. What about your friends? Your work? You've built up a good reputation as a plumber."

Lars had tried to explain that he was tired of his reputation, tired of being known as the guy you called when your bathroom flooded at three in the morning. He wanted to be known by the deer that might drink from the stream behind his cabin, by the birds that would nest in the trees he planted. He wanted to measure his days by the sun's movement across the sky rather than by the relentless ticking of his phone's clock.

But they couldn't understand, any of them. His mother had cried and accused him of abandoning the family. His ex-wife Helena had called him selfish and irresponsible, though why she cared what he did with his life after their divorce was beyond his comprehension. Even his old friend Gunnar from trade school had shaken his head and muttered something about midlife crisis and suggested he buy a motorcycle instead.

Only his gardener had seemed to understand. This was perhaps the strangest part of Lars's imagined life, the detail that had surprised even him when it emerged from his subconscious onto the page. In reality, Lars had never employed a gardener, had never even had a proper garden beyond a few wilted herbs on his apartment balcony. But in his alternate life, he'd inherited a small house with a decent-sized yard, and maintaining it had proven beyond his abilities. Enter Erik Lindqvist, a man perhaps ten years younger than Lars with dirt permanently embedded under his fingernails and an encyclopedic knowledge of soil composition and growing seasons.

Erik was quiet by nature, the sort of person who could work alongside you for hours without feeling the need to fill the silence with meaningless chatter. When Lars had explained his hermit plan, Erik had simply nodded and continued pruning the rosebush he'd been working on.

"Makes sense," he'd said finally. "Too many people in the world think they need to be around other people all the time. Nothing wrong with solitude if that's what feeds your soul."

It was Erik who had helped Lars research properties, who had driven with him to look at potential sites, who had offered practical advice about things like water sources and soil quality and how to determine if a piece of land was truly as isolated as it appeared. He'd even volunteered to help with the initial building, to stay for a week or two and help Lars construct the basic framework of his new life before leaving him to his chosen solitude.

But then everything had changed, as things have a way of doing when you least expect them. The change had come not through any fault or decision of Lars's, but through Erik's actions, through a moment of violence that had transformed both their lives in ways neither could have anticipated.

It had happened on a Tuesday evening in late September, when the days were growing shorter and the leaves were just beginning to turn. Erik had been working late, trying to finish winterizing the garden before the first frost arrived. Lars had gone inside to prepare dinner, leaving Erik alone with his thoughts and his work. Later, Lars would wonder if things might have been different if he'd stayed outside, if his presence might have prevented what happened next.

The man who appeared in the garden that evening was a stranger to Lars, though Erik seemed to recognize him immediately. From his kitchen window, Lars could see them talking, could observe the tension in their body language even if he couldn't hear their words. Erik had straightened up from the flower bed he'd been working in, his hands still holding the small spade he'd been using to plant bulbs for next spring. The stranger was gesticulating wildly, his face red with anger or alcohol or both.

Lars had watched from the window as the confrontation escalated, his dinner forgotten on the stove behind him. The stranger stepped closer to Erik, jabbing his finger toward Erik's chest in an aggressive manner that made Lars's stomach tighten with unease. Even through the glass, he could see the way Erik's shoulders tensed, the careful manner in which he set down his gardening tools and took a step backward. There was something in Erik's posture that spoke of experience with violence, a weary recognition that this situation was spiraling beyond the point of reasonable discourse.

The sound of raised voices finally penetrated the window, though Lars still couldn't make out individual words. He found himself moving toward the back door, his hand already reaching for the handle, when everything changed in the space between one heartbeat and the next. The stranger lunged forward, his hands outstretched toward Erik's throat, and Erik's response was swift and decisive. The gardening spade, which moments before had been used to plant bulbs that would bloom in the spring, became something else entirely as it connected with the stranger's skull with a sound that carried clearly across the yard despite the closed window.

Lars stood frozen in his doorway as the stranger crumpled to the ground, his body folding in on itself like a marionette whose strings had been suddenly severed. Erik remained standing over him, the bloodied spade still gripped in his hands, his chest rising and falling with rapid, shallow breaths. For a long moment, neither of them moved, as if the weight of what had just occurred needed time to settle into the space between them like dust after an explosion.

When Erik finally looked up and met Lars's eyes through the gathering darkness, his face was pale but eerily calm. He dropped the spade beside the motionless figure and walked slowly toward the house, his work boots leaving dark prints on the grass that was already beginning to glisten with evening dew. Lars stepped aside to let him pass, and Erik moved directly to the kitchen sink, where he began washing his hands with the methodical thoroughness of a surgeon preparing for an operation.

"He's dead," Erik said without turning around, his voice carrying no more emotion than if he were commenting on the weather. "I felt his skull give way under the blade. There's no coming back from that kind of damage." He continued scrubbing his hands, the water running pink as it swirled down the drain, and Lars found himself noting the strange domesticity of the scene. Here was a man who had just committed murder, calmly using the same sink where Lars washed his breakfast dishes each morning.

Lars moved to the window and looked out at the still figure lying among the flower beds. From this distance, the man looked almost peaceful, as if he had simply decided to take a nap among the chrysanthemums that Erik had planted the week before. But there was something unnatural about the angle of his head, something that spoke clearly of the finality of what had transpired in those few seconds of violence.

"Who was he?" Lars asked, surprised by the steadiness of his own voice. He had expected to feel panic, horror, the urgent need to call the police and report what had happened. Instead, he found himself filled with a strange sense of calm, as if this moment had been inevitable from the beginning, written into the fabric of their relationship long before either of them had recognized it.

Erik finished washing his hands and dried them carefully on the kitchen towel that hung beside the sink. He folded the towel with precise movements and set it back in its place before finally turning to face Lars. His eyes held a weight that hadn't been there an hour earlier, the kind of burden that settles permanently into a person's bones once they've crossed certain lines.

"His name was Marcus Holmberg," Erik said, moving to the kitchen table and sinking into one of the wooden chairs that Lars had inherited from his grandmother. "We grew up in the same neighborhood in Angered. He's been looking for me for almost three years now, ever since I testified against him in a case involving his younger brother." Erik's hands lay flat on the table's surface, and Lars noticed that despite the thorough washing, there was still dirt embedded beneath his fingernails from the evening's gardening work.

The story that emerged over the next hour was one of old grudges and family loyalty taken to dangerous extremes. Marcus's brother David had been involved in a drug-related shooting that had left two people wounded and a third permanently paralyzed. Erik had witnessed the incident while walking home from work late one evening, had seen David Holmberg fire the shots that had shattered three families and sent ripples of trauma through an entire community. When the police had come asking questions, Erik had done what he believed was right, had told the truth about what he had seen despite the warnings from neighbors who understood the potential consequences of cooperation with authorities.

David Holmberg had been sentenced to twelve years in prison, and Marcus had sworn vengeance against the man whose testimony had sealed his brother's fate. Erik had been forced to leave Angered, to abandon the small landscaping business he had built over years of careful work, to essentially disappear from his old life and start over somewhere new. He had thought that taking the job as Lars's gardener would provide the anonymity and peace he needed, that a quiet residential neighborhood far from his old haunts would offer sanctuary from the ghosts of his past.

"I should have known he would find me eventually," Erik continued, his voice taking on the flat, resigned tone of a man who has accepted the inevitable. "Marcus was always persistent, even as a child. He never forgot a slight, never forgave anyone who crossed his family. I suppose I thought that three years would be enough, that he would move on to other concerns and leave me to live my life in peace."

Lars found himself studying Erik's face in the soft light of the kitchen lamp, searching for signs of remorse or fear or any of the emotions he imagined should accompany such a confession. Instead, he saw only a deep weariness, the exhaustion of a man who had been running for years and had finally been forced to stop and turn and face his pursuer. There was something almost liberating about Erik's expression, as if the act of killing Marcus Holmberg had freed him from a burden he had carried for far too long.

"What do we do now?" Lars asked, and even as the words left his mouth, he was struck by his use of the plural pronoun. When had this become a shared problem rather than Erik's crisis alone? He should be calling the police, should be distancing himself from what had happened in his garden, should be thinking about his own safety and reputation. Instead, he found himself mentally cataloging the tools in his garage, wondering which ones might be useful for digging, calculating how long it would take to dispose of a body in a way that would never be discovered.

Erik looked at him with something that might have been gratitude mixed with surprise. "You don't have to involve yourself in this," he said carefully. "This is my problem, my choice, my consequences to face. You could call the police right now and tell them you witnessed a murder in your garden. Claim you were too shocked to intervene, too frightened to act. No one would blame you for that reaction."

But even as Erik offered him an escape route, Lars knew with certainty that he would not take it. Something had shifted in the space between Marcus Holmberg's death and this moment, some fundamental alteration in his understanding of himself and his place in the world. For years, he had lived a careful, measured existence, paying his taxes and following rules and never coloring outside the lines that society had drawn for him. He had been Lars the reliable plumber, Lars the responsible citizen, Lars the man who could be counted on to do the right thing according to other people's definitions of rightness.

But as he looked out at the body lying in his garden, at the man who had helped him plant flowers and plan his escape to a hermit's life, Lars felt something wake up inside him that had been sleeping for years. It was a recognition of possibility, of the freedom that comes when you finally step outside the boundaries that have defined your existence. Marcus Holmberg had come to Erik's garden seeking violence and had found death instead, but his death had inadvertently opened a door that Lars had never even known existed.

"We bury him," Lars said, the words coming out with a decisiveness that surprised them both. "Tonight, while the rain covers any sound we might make. My neighbor to the east is visiting her daughter in Stockholm this week, and the Peterssons on the west side sleep like the dead once they've had their evening wine. We dig a hole deep enough that he'll never be found, and then we plant something on top of it. Something that will grow and thrive and make the spot look like it's been undisturbed for years."

Erik stared at him for a long moment, and Lars could see him reassessing everything he thought he knew about the quiet plumber who had hired him to tend a modest suburban garden. "You understand what you're suggesting," Erik said finally. "If we do this, there's no going back. We become accomplices, conspirators. We become criminals."

The word hung in the air between them like smoke from a fire that could not be extinguished. Criminals. Lars turned the concept over in his mind, examining it from different angles, and found that it did not frighten him as much as he had expected it would. Perhaps because he had already been planning to withdraw from society anyway, the prospect of placing himself permanently outside its laws seemed less like a catastrophe and more like an acceleration of an inevitable process.

**Chapter 2**

The rain continued its relentless assault on the windows as Lars and Erik prepared for the work ahead of them. In the harsh fluorescent light of the garage, they moved with the careful efficiency of men who understood that their freedom depended on the thoroughness of their actions. Lars had changed into his oldest work clothes, garments already stained with years of plumbing emergencies and home repair projects, while Erik remained in the earth-stained clothing he had been wearing when Marcus Holmberg arrived to settle old scores in a suburban garden.

The tools they gathered seemed almost mundane in their ordinariness: two shovels with worn wooden handles, a pickaxe for breaking through the harder clay soil beneath the topsoil, a wheelbarrow to transport the displaced earth, and a collection of plastic tarps that Lars had accumulated over years of protecting furniture during various home improvement projects. They worked in near silence, communicating through glances and gestures, as if speaking aloud might somehow make their intentions more real or more damning.

Erik had suggested a location near the back corner of the property, where a cluster of mature birch trees would provide natural camouflage and where the existing landscape would make the disturbance of fresh digging less noticeable. The spot was also conveniently distant from the house, far enough that any future settling of the soil would not threaten the foundation or require explanation to visiting utility workers or curious neighbors. It was the kind of practical thinking that Lars was beginning to associate with his gardener, the same methodical approach that Erik brought to pruning roses or planning seasonal plantings.

They had wrapped Marcus Holmberg's body in one of the plastic tarps, securing it with duct tape in a manner that was both respectful and efficient. The dead man's face was mercifully covered, allowing them to think of their burden as simply another landscaping project rather than the mortal remains of someone who had walked into this garden with his own plans and grievances and expectations for how the evening would unfold. Lars found himself grateful for this small mercy, for the way the blue plastic transformed a human tragedy into something more manageable and less likely to haunt his dreams.

The digging proved more difficult than either man had anticipated, despite Erik's familiarity with the soil composition and drainage patterns of the property. The recent rain had turned the upper layers into a sticky, clinging mud that adhered to their shovels and made each scoop of earth a laborious process. Below that, they encountered the dense clay that Lars remembered from when he had installed the French drain along the foundation three years earlier, clay that required the pickaxe and considerable effort to break apart into manageable chunks.

They took turns with the more strenuous work, one man digging while the other served as lookout and rested muscles that were unaccustomed to such sustained physical labor. Lars discovered that his years of crawling through cramped spaces and wrestling with stubborn pipes had given him a wiry strength that served him well in this endeavor, while Erik's daily work in gardens and landscapes had developed the kind of endurance that allowed him to maintain a steady rhythm even as fatigue began to accumulate in his shoulders and back.

By midnight, they had excavated a hole approximately seven feet long, four feet wide, and nearly six feet deep. The dimensions were generous by necessity, allowing not only for the body but also for the layer of lime that Erik had retrieved from the garden shed, a substance intended to accelerate decomposition and minimize any odors that might eventually attract the attention of animals or inquisitive humans.
